title: Learning and Instruction
abstract: The internal/external frame of reference (I/E) model posits that students' academic self-concept in one domain (e.g., math) is positively associated with achievement in the same domain but negatively associated with achievement in a comparison domain (e.g., English). Whereas academic self-concept encompasses self-ratings of achievement, peer academic reputation (PAR) encompasses peer ratings of the same achievement and PAR was shown to have an incremental predictive effect on a range of positive academic outcomes. Considering the importance of PAR, we hypothesized that the I/E model would also apply to PAR both as predictor and as outcome. We tested this hypothesis in a sample of 850 seventhgrade students in 47 classes in math and English. Therein, PAR was measured in a round-robin design where students rated each classmate's level of achievement. We tested I/E models with academic selfconcept and PAR as outcomes. Results supported the I/E model for academic self-concept as outcome with academic achievement and PAR as predictor but not for PAR as outcome with achievement as predictor. For PAR as outcome, the effects across domains were positive rather than negative. These results were consistent across replications over three years using the same sample. Thus, whereas academic self-concept was characterized by contrasts between domains, PAR was characterized by assimilation between domains.

abstract.text: The internal/external frame of reference (I/E) model posits that students' academic self-concept in one domain (e.g., math) is positively associated with achievement in the same domain but negatively associated with achievement in a comparison domain (e.g., English). Whereas academic self-concept encompasses self-ratings of achievement, peer academic reputation (PAR) encompasses peer ratings of the same achievement and PAR was shown to have an incremental predictive effect on a range of positive academic outcomes. Considering the importance of PAR, we hypothesized that the I/E model would also apply to PAR both as predictor and as outcome. We tested this hypothesis in a sample of 850 seventhgrade students in 47 classes in math and English. Therein, PAR was measured in a round-robin design where students rated each classmate's level of achievement. We tested I/E models with academic selfconcept and PAR as outcomes. Results supported the I/E model for academic self-concept as outcome with academic achievement and PAR as predictor but not for PAR as outcome with achievement as predictor. For PAR as outcome, the effects across domains were positive rather than negative. These results were consistent across replications over three years using the same sample. Thus, whereas academic self-concept was characterized by contrasts between domains, PAR was characterized by assimilation between domains.

body_text.text: When students rate their achievement in a school subject (e.g., math), there are many possible comparison standards they can use. The internal/external frame of reference model (I/E model; Marsh, 1986) highlights the effect of dimensional comparisons between students' achievement in math and their achievement in a verbal subject (e.g., English). For instance, students who are better at math than English will have a more positive rating of their math achievement and, likewise, a more negative rating of their English achievement. There is ample empirical support for the I/E model when it comes to self-ratings in the form of academic self-concept (M€ oller & Marsh, 2013; M€ oller, Müller-Kalthoff, Helm, Nagy, & Marsh, 2016; M€ oller, Pohlmann, K€ oller, & Marsh, 2009) .

cite_spans.text: M€ oller, Müller-Kalthoff, Helm, Nagy, & Marsh, 2016;
M€ oller, Pohlmann, K€ oller, & Marsh, 2009)

body_text.text: Whereas the I/E model is empirically well-supported when it comes to academic self-concept, it is unclear whether the I/E model also applies to peer-rated achievement, measured as peer academic reputation (PAR; Gest, Domitrovich, & Welsh, 2005) . Thereby, students' PAR matters theoretically and empirically. Theoretically, PAR can be described as a precursor to self-perception (Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) , and empirically, PAR has been found to be an important predictor of students' motivation, achievement, anddto some degreedtheir academic choices (Chen, Hughes, Liew, & Kwok, 2010; Denissen, Sch€ onbrodt, van Zalk, Meeus, & van Aken, 2011; Gest et al., 2005; Gest, Rulison, Davidson, & Welsh, 2008; Hughes, Dyer, Luo, & Kwok, 2009) . Thus, PAR is relevant to the I/E model in a twofold way. First, PAR might predict academic selfconcept in a manner that is similar to achievement. Second, the I/ E model has the potential to explain the formation of PAR. Yet, so far, the evidence is not conclusive (M€ oller, Helm, Müller-Kalthoff, Nagy, & Marsh, 2015) .

cite_spans.text: Denissen, Sch€ onbrodt, van Zalk, Meeus, & van Aken, 2011;

body_text.text: In the present study, we tested whether and how the I/E model applies not only to self-rated but also to peer-rated achievement. We used a rigorous design to assess PAR, in which we used a sample of 850 seventh-grade students who rated not only themselves but also all their classmates with regard to achievement in English and math. In the resulting round-robin design, it is possible to control for idiosyncratic rating behaviors, which should allow for a reliable test of the I/E model for PAR.

The internal/external frame of reference model (I/E model) was first proposed with regard to the formation of academic selfconcept (Marsh, 1986) . Academic self-concept is referred to as one's self-perception of academic achievement in a specific domain or school subject (Marsh & Shavelson, 1985) and has been shown to be a very powerful construct as it is associated with several important outcomes. For instance, academic self-concept is predictive of academic choices (Parker et al., 2012) , academic effort (Trautwein, Lüdtke, Schnyder, & Niggli, 2006) , and academic achievement (Marsh & Craven, 2006) .
body_text.section: The internal/external frame of reference model

body_text.text: The I/E model originally described two simultaneous processes in the formation of students' verbal and math self-concepts (see Fig. 1 ; M€ oller et al., 2009) . In the I/E model, students' self-concept in English is positively associated with achievement in English. But when this association is controlled for, self-concept in English is negatively associated with achievement in math (with analogous results for math self-concept). This pattern of results was supported in M€ oller et al.'s (2009) meta-analysis, which included 69 studies with a combined sample of 125,308 participants. The associations in the I/E model result in a profile of perceived strengths and weaknesses with only weak correlations between self-concepts, although the correlations between corresponding achievement scores are moderate to high (M€ oller & Marsh, 2013) .
body_text.section: The internal/external frame of reference model

body_text.text: Recently, findings regarding the I/E model were generalized in the dimensional comparison theory (DCT; M€ oller . In the context of DCT, the I/E model was extended in two directions by applying it (a) to more than two domains and (b) to a broad range of domain-specific constructs.
body_text.section: The internal/external frame of reference model

body_text.text: First, according to DCT, the I/E model is the result of characteristics of academic domains. The multidimensional model of selfconcept (Marsh & Shavelson, 1985) arranges academic domains on a continuum ranging from verbal to mathematical. Dimensional comparisons between domains that are farther apart on the continuum (e.g., math and English) should have stronger (contrast) effects than dimensional comparisons between domains that are closer (e.g., math and physics). One experiment (Helm, Mueller-Kalthoff, Nagy, & M€ oller, 2016 ) and a number of observational studies have supported this reasoning and found no effects or even positive (assimilation) effects for near comparisons (Jansen, Schroeders, Lüdtke, & Marsh, 2015; Marsh et al., 2014; Marsh, Lüdtke, et al., 2015; M€ oller, Streblow, Pohlmann, & K€ oller, 2006; Xu et al., 2013) . Similarly, students who believed in a negative correlation between mathematical and verbal abilities showed stronger contrast effects for dimensional comparisons between these domains (M€ oller, Streblow, & Pohlmann, 2006) .

cite_spans.text: M€ oller, Streblow, Pohlmann, & K€ oller, 2006;

body_text.section: The internal/external frame of reference model

body_text.text: Second, at this point, the evidence suggests that the I/E model might apply to domain-specific ratings (in dissimilar domains) in general (M€ oller et al., 2016) . So far, the I/E model has been applied to interest (Schurtz, Pfost, Nagengast, & Artelt, 2014) , academic emotions (Goetz, Frenzel, Hall, & Pekrun, 2008) , intrinsic motivation (Marsh, Abduljabbar, et al., 2015) , and perceptions of the learning environment (Arens & M€ oller, 2016) . In addition, intervention effects targeting motivation in one domain might have negative effects on motivation in a comparison domain (Gaspard et al., 2016) . In a study on group perception, Yzerbyt, Kervyn, and Judd (2008) found results similar to the I/E model: Groups that were perceived as high in "warmth" were perceived as low in "competence" and vice versa (M€ oller et al., 2015) . Finally, Helm, Abele, Müller-Kalthoff, and M€ oller (2017) found that self-ratings of agency and communion (the "Big Two," e.g.; Gebauer, Sedikides, Lüdtke, & Neberich, 2014) were predicted by peer ratings of agency and communion similar to the I/E model: Peer ratings of agency positively predicted self-ratings of agency, but they negatively predicted self-ratings of communion (and vice versa).

cite_spans.text: Helm, Abele, Müller-Kalthoff, and M€ oller (2017)

body_text.section: The internal/external frame of reference model

body_text.text: Peer ratings of achievement and specifically peer academic reputation (PAR; Gest et al., 2005) are a relevant construct in educational psychology. James (1890) had already noted that how an individual is recognized by others represents an important part of the individual's self (termed the social self). A similar notion was put forward by Leary and Baumeister (2000) , who described selfesteem as a reflection of how others value an individual. And finally, theories in educational psychology have proposed that significant others' ratings of a student shape that student's selfperception (Usher & Pajares, 2008; Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) .

But moreover, studies on PAR have consistently shown that PAR predicts multiple indicators of positive academic development beyond and in addition to a positive self-perception. Gest et al. (2005 Gest et al. ( , 2008 found that PAR was associated with academic achievement, effort, and general academic self-concept. It is important to note that they found that PAR predicted school grades over and above earlier grades over the course of several years (and similarly, that grades predicted PAR over and above earlier PAR). Similarly, Hughes et al. (2009) found that PAR predicted teacherrated effort, teacher-rated achievement in math and reading, and performance on a reading test (but not on a math test) 1 year later, when prior values on all measures including prior achievement were controlled for. Chen et al. (2010) added to these results by finding that PAR predicted achievement on a standardized test 3 years later, when prior achievement, IQ, and economic status were controlled for. Therein, the effect of PAR on achievement was mediated by general academic self-concept and engagement. Finally, Denissen et al. (2011) found that PAR predicted and was predicted by grades on exams in a cross-lagged model in research on university students. Moreover, PAR predicted student dropout, whereas self-rated ability did not.

It is important to note that PAR needs to be distinguished from different forms of other ratings of achievement as demonstrated by Van Zanden et al. (2017) . Distinctions are warranted regarding the type of perceiver and the perceived construct. Besides peers, other ratings were studied from the perspective of parents (e.g. Dai, 2002) or teachers (e.g., Pohlmann, M€ oller, & Streblow, 2004) . Moreover, others' perceptions of a target student's achievement (e.g., "Alex is good in math") such as those captured by PAR (Gest et al., 2005) need to be distinguished from others' perceptions of a target student's self-concept (e.g., "Alex thinks that he is good in math"), which have been termed inferred self-concepts (e.g., Marsh, 1986) .

To measure PAR, multiple students in a classroom rate the achievement of a target student, and these ratings are then aggregated. Similar to general academic self-concept (Brunner et al., 2010) , PAR has often been measured as a domain-general construct (i.e., not specific to English or math; Chen et al., 2010; Gest et al., 2005; Gest et al., 2008; Hughes et al., 2009) . Nevertheless, for both academic self-concept and other kinds of selfperceptions of achievement, meta-analyses have shown that the correlation between self-perception and an achievement criterion is higher when both are measured at the same level of specificity (M€ oller et al., 2009; Valentine, DuBois, & Cooper, 2004) . For instance, the correlation between domain-specific self-concept and domain-specific achievement is higher than the correlation between general self-concept and domain-specific achievement. Similar to academic self-concept, domain-specific PAR may be more closely associated with domain-specific achievement. Moreover, studies by Marsh and colleagues (Marsh, 1986; Marsh, Smith, & Barnes, 1984) have indicated that at least peers' inferences of another student's self-concept are domain-specific as well.

PAR is a theoretically and empirically relevant construct, and the I/E model describes the formation of a wide range of ratings. Bringing the two phenomena together has the potential to improve the understanding of both. The role of PAR in the I/E model can be twofold. First, PAR can be conceptualized as a predictor of selfconcept. Second, PAR can be conceptualized as an outcome in the I/E model. First, PAR in math and in a verbal domain such as English can be tested as a predictor of academic self-concept in these domains. In general, this idea is in line with the theoretical and empirical results presented above. There, we explained that what others think about a student might be relevant for the student's self-perception (e.g., Leary & Baumeister, 2000; Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) . Furthermore, parents' ratings of achievement predicted their child's academic self-concept (Dai, 2002) , and moreover, PAR has been found to predict academic self-concept (e.g., Gest et al., 2005) . Considering PAR in two domains as a predictor of academic self-concept in two domains thus provides an extension of earlier studies. Furthermore, this notion fits with the recent extension of the I/E model that makes it possible to include a broader set of domain-specific predictors (M€ oller et al., 2016) . Recently, Helm et al. (2017) found that peer feedback predicted self-ratings of personality in the Big Two. Thus, in line with recent developments in the I/E model, peer ratings such as PAR might predict self-concept in academic domains as well.
body_text.section: The I/E model and the perception of others

body_text.text: The case is less clear with PAR as an outcome in the I/E model because little is known about its formation. As outlined above, achievement has been found to predict PAR, at least when they are measured as domain-general constructs (e.g., Gest et al., 2008) . However, considering the evidence on DCT, the I/E model can potentially help account for the formation of PAR when considered in English and math. This reasoning was outlined by M€ oller et al. (2015) who hypothesized that "dimensional comparisons influence evaluations of and by other people and groups" (p. 430). This hypothesis is based on the idea that ratings (including achievement ratings) are always made with regard to some frame of reference (Kahneman & Miller, 1986) . Evidence that the I/E model applies to a wide range of ratings corroborates the notion of a dimensional reference for PAR. Furthermore, the dissimilarity of domains such as English and mathddescribed as a major determinant of the I/E modeldshould be the same in peer and selfperception.
body_text.section: The I/E model and the perception of others

body_text.text: However, there is no conclusive evidence that the I/E model holds for the perceptions of others. Only a limited number of studies exist, and they differ regarding the investigated rating (ratings of achievement vs. inferred self-concepts), the perspective of the rater (teachers, parents, and peers), and the research methodology (experimental vs. correlational). Overall, the results do not provide a clear pattern as contrast effects emerged in some but not all studies when dimensional comparisons were investigated. Regarding inferred self-concepts, dimensional comparison effects emerged in one experimental study on teachers' inferences of students' self-concepts (Dickh€ auser, 2005) and in one correlational study on parents' inferences of students' self-concepts (Van Zanden et al., 2017) . Conversely, dimensional comparison effects did not emerge in observational studies on peers' or teachers' inferences of students' self-concepts (Marsh, 1986; Pohlmann et al., 2004) . Regarding ratings of achievement, dimensional comparison effects emerged in experimental studies on teachers' and peers' ratings of student achievement (Dickh€ auser, 2005; M€ oller, 2005 ). Yet, dimensional comparison effects did not emerge in observational studies of parents' ratings of student achievement (Dai, 2002; Van Zanden et al., 2017 ).
body_text.section: The I/E model and the perception of others

body_text.text: Yet, the extent to which the results of these studies generalize to PAR is unclear. For instance, Van Zanden et al. 2017demonstrated that with parents as perceivers, the I/E model could be found for inferred self-concepts but not for parents' ratings of achievement. In addition, whereas PAR was measured on the basis of multiple classmates' ratings of a target student (Gest et al., 2005) , the observational studies mentioned above measured inferred selfconcepts by asking single students to rate one target student Pohlmann et al., 2004) . If only single perceivers rate a target, these ratings may be confounded with idiosyncratic tendencies, leading to inflated correlations between ratings (Nestler & Back, 2015) . Studies on interpersonal perception employing multiple perceivers per target show that about 20% of the variance in interpersonal ratings is accounted for by idiosyncratic rating tendencies (termed the relationship effect; Hoyt & Kerns, 1999; Kenny, 1994) . Having multiple perceivers assess each target controls for these idiosyncratic tendencies. For instance, studies that used vignettes (and supported the I/E model with regard to ratings by others) were based on multiple perceivers per target (Dickh€ auser, 2005; M€ oller, 2005) . Taken together, there are reasons to suppose that PAR might be formed according to the I/E model, yet the evidence so far is unclear because of the types of other ratings and the different methodologies that were used in earlier studies.
body_text.section: The I/E model and the perception of others

body_text.text: PAR is a relevant construct in education that can be seen as a precursor of academic self-concept and that has incrementally predicted students' motivation, achievement, and to some degree their choices. In this study, first, we aimed to better understand the role of PAR in the prediction of academic self-concept. To do so, we tested a model with PAR as the predictor and academic self-concept as the outcome. Second, we also aimed to understand PAR's formation in terms of the I/E model. To achieve this second aim, we compared I/E models predicting self-concept in math and English with I/E models predicting PAR in math and English (with objective measures of achievement as predictors in all models). For selfconcept, we expected to find positive effects within domains and negative effects across domains, in line with the I/E model. In accordance with M€ oller et al.'s (2015, 2016) hypothesis and conceptualizations, we expected the same results for the models with PAR as the outcome in both math and English.

We conducted the study by reanalyzing data from a large-scale school achievement study with English as a foreign language and math as domains. The I/E model should apply to these domains in a German sample because the domains are located on either extreme of the continuum of verbal and mathematical domains (Marsh, Lüdtke, et al., 2015; M€ oller, Streblow, Pohlmann, et al., 2006) . In earlier observational studies, only single perceivers were asked to rate each target student. To avoid this issue, we focused our investigation on PAR, which was assessed in a round-robin design where students rated every classmate (see Fig. 2 for an example). Furthermore, we used a large sample of 850 school students and achievement measures consisting of school grades and standardized achievement tests. To corroborate our results, we replicated the analyses for all four waves that were measured in this sample.

cite_spans.text: M€ oller, Streblow, Pohlmann, et al., 2006)

body_text.text: The sample comprised data from the large-scale TRAIN study (Jonkmann, Rose, & Trautwein, 2013b) , which investigated the achievement, motivation, and well-being of students in nonacademic tracks in two federal states of Germany. We focused our analyses on classes in which round-robin data were collected. These were exclusively classes from the nonacademic track (Mittelschule) in the state of Saxony. For the main part of the analyses, we used data from the third wave of measurement in 2010 when students were in the seventh grade. Earlier studies have shown that older (and also better acquainted) students' peer ratings of achievement are more differentiated and more accurate than the peer ratings of younger (and less closely acquainted) students (Malloy, Sugarman, Montvilo, & Ben-Zeev, 1995; Malloy, Yarlas, Montvilo, & Sugarman, 1996) . Thus, we chose the measurement wave in which students had known each other for somewhat more than 2 years to ensure a reliable and valid measurement of PAR. To check whether our results would replicate in the other measurement waves, we also conducted analyses for the Grade 5, 6, and 8 samples by applying the same analytical approach. See Supplement 1 for a description of sample characteristics as well as further notes on the methods used in these grades. L€ osch et al. (2017) used data that partially overlapped with the current study in terms of students and measures.

In Grade 7, our target sample comprised 1,084 students in 48 classes. Yet, as the main focus of our study was the round-robin measurement, we had to exclude 234 students of which 229 had no round-robin data (19 were absent at the time of measurement, and 210 did not have parental consent to participate in the roundrobin measurement). On average, 79.62% (SD ¼ 14.23%) of students in each classroom participated in the round-robin design. Furthermore, we excluded 5 students in 1 class where the reliable measurement of PAR was not warranted because only five or less students participated in the round-robin measurement. In the end, we used data from 850 students in 47 classes (47.53% female, mean age ¼ 13.15, SD ¼ 0.57). Trained research assistants visited intact classrooms and administered all measures during regular school hours on 2 consecutive days.

Academic self-concept in math and English was measured with a German version of the SDQ (e.g., Marsh & O'Neill, 1984; German version: Schwanzer, Trautwein, Lüdtke, & Sydow, 2005) . The scale consisted of four items per domain and had a reliability of a ¼ .85 in math and a ¼ .80 in English. Math items were "I am good at math," "I am just not talented in math," "Math is easy for me," and "In math, I am always struggling." The English items were "I am good at English," "I am just not talented in English," "I do not particularly like English," and "I struggle to understand anything that has to do with English."

cite_spans.text: German version: Schwanzer, Trautwein, Lüdtke, & Sydow, 2005)

body_text.text: Peer ratings of math and English achievement were assessed in a round-robin design (see Fig. 2 for an example). Each student had to rate all classmates with the items "This student is good at math" and "This student is good at English," which could be answered on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much so). Altogether, we analyzed data from 7,662 dyads (where each student was rated by at least one other student). Using these roundrobin data, we estimated PAR in math and English as students' target effect (see the statistical procedure below).

Achievement was measured by grades and performance on a standardized achievement test. Grades were obtained from the school administration. We used the previous year's final grades in Fig. 2 . Illustration of a univariate round-robin design with four participants (Alex, Beth, Charlie, and Daisy). Student i's rating of student j's achievement is represented by x ij . The self-concept of student i is represented by (x ii ). The arrows indicate effects that are estimated in the social relations model (Kenny, 1994) : the perceiver or row effects u i (i.e., how student i tends to rate the achievement of others) and the target or column effects v j (i.e., how others rate the achievement of student i). The target effect can be used as a measure of PAR (Denissen et al., 2011). math and English, that is, at the end of sixth grade. In Germany, grades range from 1 (best grade) to 6 (worst grade). We recoded all grades so that high scores represent high achievement (by subtracting the grade from 6; e.g., recoding a 1 into a 5).

Second, achievement was measured with low-stakes standardized achievement tests in math and English. Both tests were designed to measure content from the curriculum, that is, what students should have learned in class throughout the school year (Rose et al., 2013) . The math test was administered according to a rotated test booklet design (Mislevy, Beaton, Kaplan, & Sheehan, 1992) that allowed us to scale the tests across measurement waves (Rose et al., 2013) . That is, due to the complex design, achievement could be measured in the same metric across each of the four waves of measurement from the TRAIN study, and at the same time, no student saw the same item twice (to prevent memory effects, etc.). We used weighted likelihood estimates (WLE) of students' test performance. Their marginal reliability (which is comparable to Cronbach's a) was .70. The English test was a listening comprehension test (Jonkmann, Rose, & Trautwein, 2013a) . The test was the same for all students and consisted of 25 items with a reliability of a ¼ .71. We used the sum score of the test as a measure of English achievement. Both tests were administered during the 2 days of measurement.
Our analyses consisted of two steps. First, we estimated PAR in math and English. Second, we analyzed I/E models for academic self-concept and PAR.

In the first step, we estimated PAR using a bivariate social relations model (SRM; Kenny, Kashy, & Cook, 2006) . The SRM methodology can be used to analyze and describe interpersonal perceptions in various domains. The univariate SRM is well known in research on interpersonal perception. However, to investigate the I/E model, we needed to model achievement ratings in two domains simultaneously. Thus, we drew on the bivariate extension of the SRM (Kenny, 1994) . Typically, the SRM is applied in a round-robin design (Kenny, 1994) . Variance in ratings is attributed to individual differences stemming from three sources. The perceiver effect describes a tendency to rate peers as competent (e.g., How competent does Alex think his classmates are in math?). The target effect describes a tendency to be rated as competent (e.g., How competent do Alex' classmates think he is in math?). Finally, the relationship effect describes the unique tendency of one student to rate one other student and cannot be separated from measurement error (e.g., How competent does Alex think that Beth in particular is in math?). The target effect can be used as a measure of students' PAR (Denissen et al., 2011; Nestler & Back, 2015) .

Because the Bayesian approach is comparatively flexible, we applied it to estimate the bivariate SRM (Lüdtke, Robitzsch, Kenny, & Trautwein, 2013) by using the software WinBUGS in R with the package R2winBUGS (Lunn, Thomas, Best, & Spiegelhalter, 2000; R Core Team, 2015; Sturtz, Ligges, & Gelman, 2005) . For all parameters, we chose noninformative priors (see Lüdtke et al., 2013) . Thus, the parameter estimates were mainly based on observed data and could be interpreted similarly to maximum-likelihood estimates (Nestler, 2015) . For parameter estimates of the SRM analysis, see Supplement 2 and Table S1 .

In the subsequent analyses, we corrected for the unreliability of PAR (i.e., the target effect; see Bonito & Kenny, 2010) by applying the multiple imputation method from the missing data literature (Yang & Seltzer, 2015 ; see also; Enders, 2010). That is, in the estimation of the SRM, we specified a background model in which we included grades, achievement tests, and academic self-concept in both domains as predictors of the target effect in both domains. For further statistical analyses, we then drew 50 plausible values (see Asparouhov & Muth en, 2010) from the posterior distribution of the target effect (see Bodner, 2008) . Finally, we aggregated statistical estimates across these 50 imputations using Rubin's rule (Rubin, 1987) via the R package miceadds for the correlations (Robitzsch, 2015) and via procedures to handle multiple imputations implemented in Mplus 7.1 for the I/E models (Muthen & Muthen, 2012) . We used this approach to correctly estimate associations between the target effects and the other measures. See also L€ osch et al. 2017, where this strategy was initially used.

In the second step, we investigated several I/E models for academic self-concept and PAR as structural equation models. In the basic I/E model, math self-concept is regressed on math and English achievement, and simultaneously, English self-concept is regressed on English and math achievement (M€ oller et al., 2009) . A negative regression coefficient across domains (e.g., English self-concept on math achievement) indicates dimensional comparison effects. In the basic model, we used grades and standardized tests as achievement measures. We adapted this basic specification and additionally used the target effect (as a measure of PAR) first as a predictor and then as an outcome. Altogether, we specified five I/E models: two basic models with self-concept as the outcome and either grades or achievement test as the predictor, one model with the target effect as the predictor and academic self-concept as the outcome, and two models with the target effect as the outcome and either grades or achievement test as the predictor. We specified self-concept as measured by the self-concept items. We controlled for unreliability in achievement test scores by specifying them as measured with a single indicator and constrained their residual variance to their sampling variance multiplied with 1 -their reliability (0.44 in math and 4.33 in English). The I/E models were estimated in Mplus 7.1 (Muthen & Muthen, 2012) . We adjusted the standard errors to account for the clustered data structure (i.e., students clustered in classes). For all models, we report standardized coefficients.

The manifest correlations of all investigated variables are presented in Table 1 . Both achievement measures were correlated with the corresponding self-concept and PAR measures, for instance, in math, the correlation between grades and self-concept was r ¼ .36, and the correlation between grades and PAR was r ¼ .74. Both the students themselves and their peers were relatively accurate, but the correlations differed significantly. That is, the correlations between PAR and achievement were significantly stronger than the correlations between self-concept and achievement in math (standardized test: t ¼ 4.15, p < .001; grades: t ¼ 14.71, p < .001) as well as English (standardized test: t ¼ 4.99, p < .001; grades: t ¼ 10.5, p < .001). Furthermore, self-concept and PAR were correlated as well (e.g., r ¼ .40 in math). This result indicates that students had a moderate to high level of self-other agreement with their peers. Across domains, the correlations between the same constructs measured in math and English showed an interesting pattern. Achievement measures across domains had a moderate to high correlation, for instance, the correlation between grades in math and English was r ¼ .57. As is usually found, the correlation between self-concepts in math and English was substantially lower (r ¼ .17). These patterns point to dimensional comparison effects with contrasts for self-ratings. However, across domains, PAR scores were highly correlated (r ¼ .94). This pattern indicated no dimensional contrasts for peer ratings.

In Fig. 3 , we present the results for the I/E models. In Wave 3, self-concept in one domain was positively associated with achievement in the same domain. The usual I/E model emerged with grades as predictors: A good grade in math was related to a higher self-concept in math (with a coefficient of 0.53, SE ¼ 0.04, p < .001) but a lower self-concept in English, when English grades were controlled for (with a coefficient of À0.14, SE ¼ 0.06, p ¼ .027). Similarly, a good grade in English was related to a higher selfconcept in English (with a coefficient of 0.54, SE ¼ 0.06, p < .001) but a lower self-concept in math, when grades in math were controlled for (with a coefficient of À0.19, SE ¼ 0.05, p < .001). However, there were no effects across domains when the achievement tests were used as predictors.
body_text.section: I/E models for self-and peer ratings

body_text.text: A similar picture emerged for PAR as a predictor and selfconcept as an outcome in Wave 3. PAR in math was associated with a higher self-concept in math (with a coefficient of 1.43, SE ¼ 0.14, p < .001) but with a lower self-concept in English (with a coefficient of À0.56, SE ¼ 0.14, p < .001). Similarly, PAR in English was associated with a higher self-concept in English (with a coefficient of 0.94, SE ¼ 0.14, p < .001) but with a lower self-concept in math (with a coefficient of À1.04, SE ¼ 0.14, p < .001). Thus, both internal and external frames of reference could be found with PAR as the predictor.
body_text.section: I/E models for self-and peer ratings

body_text.text: A different picture emerged when PAR was the outcome in Wave 3. As was the case for self-concept, achievement in one domain was positively associated with PAR in that domain for both achievement measures. For instance, the coefficient for math grades predicting PAR in math was 0.57 SE ¼ 0.04, p < .001. Contrary to the results for self-concept, achievement in one domain was also positively associated with PAR in the other domain. For instance, the coefficient for math grades predicting PAR in English was 0.42, SE ¼ 0.04, p < .001. Apparently, students with higher achievement in math were rated as more competent in both math and English. Similarly, students with higher achievement in English were rated as more competent in both English and math. Thus, the internal contrast effect did not emerge. Achievement in general was associated with a more positive rating by peers, which might indicate that peers perceived differences in achievement as smaller than they actually were. Comparing achievement tests and grades as predictors, the coefficients were higher for grades.
body_text.section: I/E models for self-and peer ratings

body_text.text: To test for the consistency of the observed effects, we replicated the analysis of the I/E models at the other three waves of measurement (for replications of zero-order correlations, see Supplement 3). For an overview of the results, see Fig. 3 . Overall, the I/E model seemed to be supported for self-concept as the outcome, yet with some variations. In all models, self-concept in one domain was positively predicted by achievement in the same domain; for instance, in Wave 1, math self-concept was predicted by the math test with a coefficient of 0.52, SE ¼ 0.05, p < .001, and English selfconcept was predicted by the English test with a coefficient of 0.25, SE ¼ 0.09, p ¼ .005. The effects across domains were significant in some but not all models. Math self-concept was predicted by the English test in Wave 2 and in Wave 4 (e.g., in Wave 4 with a coefficient of À0.21, SE ¼ 0.06, p < .001). Yet, English self-concept was only predicted by the math test in Wave 4 (with a coefficient of À0.12, SE ¼ 0.06, p ¼ .027). Conversely, using grades as the predictor, effects across domains emerged in Waves 3 and 4. In Wave 4, math self-concept was predicted by English grades with a coefficient of À0.11, SE ¼ 0.06, p ¼ .048, and English self-concept was predicted by the math grades with a coefficient of À0.17, SE ¼ 0.05, p < .001. Overall, the I/E model emerged in Wave 4 when the students were oldest.

Regarding PAR as the predictor, typical results for the I/E model emerged; that is, a positive PAR in math was related to a higher selfconcept in math (in Wave 2 with a coefficient of 1.12, SE ¼ 0.15, p < .001) but a lower self-concept in English when PAR in English was controlled for (in Wave 2 with a coefficient of À0.35, SE ¼ 0.17, p ¼ .035). Similarly, a positive PAR in English was related to a higher self-concept in English (in Wave 2 with a coefficient of 0.67, SE ¼ 0.17, p < .001) but a lower self-concept in math when PAR in math was controlled for (in Wave 2 with a coefficient of À0.73, SE ¼ 0.15, p < .001). The only result that diverged from the I/E model was in Wave 1, where the effect of PAR in math on English selfconcept was not significant with a coefficient of À0.26, SE ¼ 0.22, p ¼ .232.

Regarding PAR as the outcome, the results were consistent as well. Achievement in one domain was positively associated with PAR in that domain for both achievement measures. For instance, in Wave 1, PAR in math was predicted by grades in math with a coefficient of 0.39, SE ¼ 0.03, p < .001, and PAR in English was predicted by grades in English with a coefficient of 0.52, SE ¼ 0.03, p < .001. However, still in contrast to the results for academic selfconcept as the outcome, achievement in one domain was also positively associated with PAR in the other domain. For instance, in Wave 1, PAR in English was predicted by grades in math with a coefficient of 0.27, SE ¼ 0.04, p < .001 and PAR in math was predicted by grades in English with a coefficient of 0.43, SE ¼ 0.04, p < .001. That is, we were able to replicate the Wave 3 results in the other three measurement waves. There was only one exception in Wave 2, where PAR in math was not predicted by the test in English with a coefficient of 0.02, SE ¼ 0.07, p ¼ .754. In sum, students with higher achievement in math were rated as more competent in both math and English. Similarly, students with higher achievement in English were rated as more competent in both English and math. Achievement in general was associated with a more positive rating by peers.

PAR can be described as a constituent of academic self-concept, and it was shown to predict multiple indicators of students' academic success. In the framework of the I/E model, we sought to understand PAR as a predictor of academic self-concept and as an outcome of dimensional comparisons. By reanalyzing data from a large-scale school achievement study, first, we tested PAR as a predictor of academic self-concept in the I/E model; and second, we tested PAR as an outcome with achievement as the predictor in the I/E model. We compared both conceptualizations with the more common I/E model in math and English with achievement as a predictor of academic self-concept. To overcome the issues found in earlier studies, we measured PAR in a round-robin design in which students rated each of their classmates. Our results supported the I/ E model with self-concept as the outcome when grades were used as the achievement measure but not when tests were used as the achievement measure (see Limitations below). That is, grades in one domain (e.g., English) had a positive effect on self-concept in the corresponding domain (e.g., English) but a negative effect on self-concept in the noncorresponding domain (e.g., math). We found the same pattern when PAR was used as the predictor of academic self-concept. However, the I/E model was not supported when PAR was the outcome. Achievement in one domain had a positive effect on PAR in the corresponding domain, but it also had a positive effect on PAR in the noncorresponding domain.

Our results supported the hypothesis that PAR would predict academic self-concept in the I/E model. This result is in line with the theoretical consideration that PAR is a precursor to academic self-concept (cf. Leary & Baumeister, 2000; Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) , and it is in line with a more general conception of the I/E model (M€ oller et al., 2016) . Similarly, our results fit with the results presented by Helm et al. (2017) , who were able to show that selfratings of personality were predicted by peer ratings or feedback on personality in accordance with the I/E model. According to Helm et al.'s (2017) interpretation, our results might indicate that students base their self-concept on inferences they make about others' perceptions as well as on feedback by peers. However, our study was correlational so we cannot determine the exact processes of self-concept formation. To substantiate our results, an experimental approach that shows an effect of PAR in multiple domains on academic self-concept is needed. Moreover, a follow-up question for our results is whether students base their self-concept on objective achievement or on PAR.

Conversely, regarding PAR as an outcome in the I/E model, we did not find typical results. On the one hand, we found evidence for social reference effects (Marsh, 1986) . That is, the effect within domains indicated that peers could accurately rank order their classmates' achievement in both domains. Yet on the other hand, the evidence for dimensional reference effects was more ambiguous as we found positive effects across domains. This result differs from studies that found negative cross-domain effects for a broad range of self-ratings (M€ oller et al., 2009) , and our result is also different from studies on inferred self-concepts, which found no cross-domain effect Pohlmann et al., 2004) . In fact, our result is more in line with more recent conceptualizations of the I/E model that consider positive effects across domains as indicators of an assimilation effect (M€ oller et al., 2016) , for instance, for academic self-concept in similar domains (Helm et al., 2016; Jansen et al., 2015; Marsh, Lüdtke, et al., 2015) . Following this conceptualization, the positive cross-domain effect with PAR as the outcome could indicate that classmates integrate their perception of a target student's achievement into a domain-general perception. That is, students seem to construe one rank order of general competence within classes.

Yet, so far, we can provide only preliminary explanations of the processes that potentially underlie the effect. Prior studies that found positive effects across domains explained them as a result of the (perceived) similarity of domains (e.g., M€ oller, Streblow, & Pohlmann, 2006) . If features of domains were the only explanation for dimensional comparisons effects, this would imply that in other perception, the domains would be perceived differently than in self-perceptiondwhich may be rather unlikely. Otherwise, students might not be able to differentiate their classmates' achievements across multiple domains. For instance, they might not be equally acquainted with all of their peers, and accordingly, they would need to rely on heuristics to rate the achievement of the peers they do not know well. Such a heuristic might consist of using a general impression of competence. If this was the case, acquaintance could be a moderator of cross-domain effects. That is, a negative cross-domain effect for PAR might be present only for well-acquainted students. Finally, students might not be motivated to rate their peers in differentiated ways. That is, as M€ oller and Marsh (2013) argued, motives such as self-enhancement or selfverification (cf. Leary, 2007) would drive students to internally compare their achievement. Regarding their classmates, students might not be interested in acquiring a similarly differentiated perception. In the end, we cannot differentiate between these explanations on the basis of our data. Further studies that are able to describe processes and moderators in the formation of PAR in multiple domains will be necessary.

It is interesting, however, that PAR was strongly associated with achievement in the same domain. That is, despite the positive cross-domain effects in the I/E model, the zero-order correlation between PAR and achievement was significantly stronger than the correlation between academic self-concept and achievement. That is, even if classmates were not able or motivated to rate their peers in a differentiated way, their ratings were a measure that was a valid representation of students' objective achievement (see also L€ osch et al., 2017). Accordingly, students' academic self-concept differs from PAR, and this difference is associated with a lower correlation of academic self-concept with achievement. Moreover, as PAR has been found to be predictive of future achievement (Chen et al., 2010; Denissen et al., 2011; Gest et al., 2008; Hughes et al., 2009) , it is to be expected that the positive cross-domain effect in the prediction of PAR contributes to the incremental validity of PAR.

Overall, our results regarding PAR are corroborated by their consistency across all waves of measurement. That is, results for the I/E models that included PAR were nearly the same across the 4 years, thus pointing to developmental stability in the associations. Of course, these replications were not independent of each other, but rather, the same students were tested in multiple stages of their development. Accordingly, future studies should follow up on our results and investigate whether they can be replicated in different samples.

Finally, with our study, we can contribute to a better understanding of PAR. Both theoretically and empirically, PAR can be described as a relevant construct in educational psychology (e.g., Gest et al., 2008) . Our study contributes to its understanding in two ways. First, we were able to demonstrate an effect of PAR on academic self-concept that was in line with a recent conceptualization of the I/E model. Second, we were able to show that the formation of PAR is not characterized by a dimensional contrast effect but instead by dimensional assimilation effects. Furthermore, we were able to support this conclusion by applying the strong methodology of round-robin ratings as this eliminates the biases that can occur when only single perceivers are employed.

Although we found negative cross-domain effects with achievement as the predictor and academic self-concept as the outcome, we did not find negative cross-domain effects across all measurement waves. This result is puzzling as the I/E model was previously found to hold for both standardized tests and grades (M€ oller et al., 2009) , and we can only speculate about explanations. On the one hand, the achievement tests might not have elicited negative cross-domain effects because they were not salient to students or because the tests were low-stakes tests. However, as the tests were based on the students' curriculum, achievement in the tests should be relatively salient to them. Furthermore, earlier studies found negative cross-domain effects with low-stakes tests as well (e.g., Jansen et al., 2015) . Regarding the domains, students might not perceive English (as a foreign language) as a verbal domain, and this may have led to the absence of dimensional comparison effects. Contradicting this explanation is the fact that we found negative cross-domain effects when grades and PAR were used as predictors. Finally, the absence of a negative effect for tests might be related to student characteristics, especially their age. In a recent study, the I/E model was not supported for elementary school children (Lohbeck & M€ oller, 2017) . M€ oller (2005) observed a similar result and argued that dimensional comparisons require a certain level of cognitive maturity. However, students in our sample were in Grades 5 to 8 and were thus out of elementary school (which ends in Grade 4 in Germany), which rather precludes cognitive maturity as an explanation. Overall, it is likely that a combination of these factors led to the observed results, and further research is required to identify moderators of dimensional comparison effects.
body_text.section: Limitations and directions for future research

body_text.text: A different limitation of our study concerns the measurement of PAR, which could have biased the dimensional structure of PAR. Peer ratings of achievement were collected in a grid structure with classmates ordered in rows and achievement ratings in columns. Furthermore, the item format was confounded with the outcome: Academic self-concept was measured in a traditional format, whereas PAR was measured within the grid. This item format may have evoked or diminished frame of reference effects, and thus, it might have biased the correlation of PAR in math and English. However, Sparfeldt, Schilling, Rost, and Thiel (2006) tested the effect of the grid format on the dimensional structure of academic self-concept. They found that the grid was equivalent to a more traditional item format, and they furthermore found the I/E model for academic self-concept measured in the grid structure as well. Accordingly, we would argue that it is unlikely that basing the measurement of PAR on a grid structure biased our results. This argument is further supported by the similarity of our results with the results of Pohlmann et al. (2004) and , who assessed inferred self-concepts in a traditional questionnaire design and who also did not find negative cross-domain effects.
body_text.section: Limitations and directions for future research

body_text.text: Finally, characteristics of our sample may limit the generalizability of our results. In the federal state of Saxony (where the data were collected), there are two school tracks, and our sample comprised students from the lower track. These students were lower achieving and might have also been less motivated. This might affect the generalizability of our results and might have led to the lower reliability and validity of our measures, especially considering that providing peer ratings of achievement might have been arduous. That being said, results from the SRM models (see Table S1 in the supplement) indicated a sufficient amount of variation in ratings to allow for a useful interpretation of PAR (see Kenny, 1994) . Nevertheless, with regard to PAR, there is a need for more studies in diverse samples to shed more light on the generalizability of results.
body_text.section: Limitations and directions for future research

body_text.text: Peer perception has been described as a highly relevant precursor to individual students' academic success that influences their self-perception and predicts their achievement. In this study, we sought to understand the role of peer perception in the I/E model as a specific test of dimensional comparison theory (M€ oller & Marsh, 2013; M€ oller et al., 2015) . In I/E models in the domains of math and English, we found negative cross-domain effects when PAR was used to predict academic self-concept, but we found positive cross-domain effects when achievement was used to predict PAR. Because of these results, it seems that peer perception elicits dimensional contrasts in the self-perception of achievement, but conversely, peer perception of achievement seems to be marked by dimensional assimilation.
T. L€ osch et al. / Learning and Instruction 52 (2017) 80e89

FIGREF0.text: The internal/external frame of reference model (I/E model) according to M€ oller et al.(2009). Achievement in one domain has a positive effect on self-concept in the same domain (þ) but a negative effect on self-concept in the comparison domain (À).

FIGREF1.text: Results of the I/E models in all four measurement waves. The two upper rows show I/E models with self-concept as the outcome; the bottom row shows PAR as the outcome. On the left, standardized tests are used as predictors; on the right, grades are used as predictors; in the middle, PAR is used as the predictor. Standardized coefficients are shown. Coefficients refer to Wave 1 / Wave 2 / Wave 3 / Wave 4. Coefficients next to dashed lines refer to dimensional comparisons. *p < 0.05.
